content: everyone why lock here welcome back the
teleport areum I did a few episodes ago was a huge hit bunch of you asked me to
do a hyperspace oubliette for the necrons so I did for those unfamiliar
with what this is all about this is a little diorama to put models on in
reserve in Warhammer 40k some units are able to come in later in the game and
the rule is written in a flavorful way so here's the datasheet for the death
marks unit and you can see they have a special hunters from hyperspace during
deployment you can set up this unit in a hyperspace oubliette instead of placing
it on the battlefield at the end of any of your movement phases the death marks
can slip back into reality set them up anywhere on the battlefield that is more
than nine inches away from enemy models most of that is unnecessary it's just
flavor fluff the mechanical part of the rule just says to set them up later more
than nine inches away from enemy models but wouldn't it be cool if you actually
had a hyperspace booboo yet on the table next to the game but your models are set
up on just like the rule says yeah I think so so let's go build one
the main ingredient I used is as always chipboard
this is graphics medium chipboard it's the brown slab you'll find at the back
of a legal pad but you can buy it in bulk there's a link in the video
description below so I set up five death marks and found that a shelf size of
about ten by six and a half centimeters would fit them comfortably I cut for
such rectangles two will be needed for each shelf this is a Christmas light
specifically the LED kind with a twist the bulb part comes off pretty easily
and then by bending the leads out it can be liberated from the chassis I did a
quick test with a standard three volt coin battery and this will work on one
of those rectangles i measured down the center lengthwise and on that line
marked inwards by 25 millimeters punched holes through with those points inserted
the LEDs bent the leads flat and secured them in place with hot glue on the other
side then I soldered on li wires to the leads and hot glued them down as well
in the open areas I hot-glued two slabs of chipboard like this and then hot
glued the other large rectangle on them to create a sandwich that hides the
wires the back of the oubliette is double corrugated cardboard but single
corrugated would work or even foam board here's a diagram of its dimensions
I spotted where the wires would go through punched holes and then fed all
four wires through the ledge gets attached with a healthy bead of hot glue
notice that there's an empty channel in the back due to that chipboard sandwich
this is by design it means the hot glue will seep in have lots of surface area
to stick to and won't squish out because it has some place to go just be sure and
hold still for a solid three minutes to be totally sure that it hardens while
perpendicular the top was done in the same way except it's obviously not ten
centimeters wide and also you need to add a few millimeters to the depth
depending on the thickness of your backing in my case with the double
corrugated cardboard it was seven millimeters also I measured out a 30
millimeter square in the center and cut it out punched holes and prepared LEDs
just as before and then I actually base coated with black acrylic craft paint
right now around the LEDs the exposed edges and both sides of the slab then I
have these fluorescent green plastic rods leftover from when I did a big
nekron eBay rescue the brand is plaster upped I chopped five small lengths and
hot glued them over the square like this then completed the sandwich exactly as
before again pre base coating with black this pre base coating is so that we
don't have to take wet black paint anywhere near those rods so much easier
this was attached to the top of the backing but like against its edge
instead of on top of it if that makes sense
you can see where I'm putting a hot glue this is why earlier I said to add a few
millimeters to the depth then I just started measuring out
rectangles of chipboard to fill out the sides of the structure and those are
attached with hot glue to the main body tea lights are a great cheap source for
both miniature switches and three volt coin batteries just tear them apart and
you get both pieces more cheaply than you would ordering from digi-key your
Mouser plus save the flickering LED using a future project so just like in
the teleport areum episode I decided to try a six volt battery by hot gluing two
batteries together in series and the result is a much stronger brighter color
without burning up the LEDs so no resistor needed due to the inherent
resistance of the batteries good to go I got the whole circuit soldered together
on the back including the battery and switch making sure to leave a large open
area in the middle and making sure that nothing was too close to an edge such
that you might see it if you're looking at this thing from the side a quick test
looking good for a refresher on custom lighting circuit design and soldering
check out episode 56 now on the sides of the blue blue yet those edges are flimsy
where they meet so I took some food box cardstock any card stock would work here
a pre-scored 1/2 inch strip down the middle folded it and hot glued it on to
stabilize those edges and really make this thing crazy strong not really sure
of where to go next I base coated the entire inside with
black this is cross stitching mesh sometimes referred to as granny grating
available at literally any crafting store that sells sewing supplies it's
plastic so it needs a flat primer coat first like krylon or rust-oleum and then
I over brushed it with a metallic silver cut a rectangle to size and attached it
to the shelves using super glue super glue is good here for that plastic and
doesn't have blobs showing like hot glue wood
that done I cut some chipboard strips
and hot glue them on to cover up the exposed front edges making sure that the
two for the shelves are flush with the grading this is easy to do because
there's several seconds of working time with hot glue and you can feel with the
pads of your fingers when the grading and the edge of the chipboard are nice
and flush then I said about base coating the rest of it in plain black and that
takes me about 25 seconds so why don't we take that time to go ahead and do all
of the annoying youtuber calls to action there are multiple ways to support the
channel if you find the content helpful number one like subscribe reminder bail
number two patreon why LOX armory number three Amazon affiliate links just use
the links in the video description below when you buy stuff totally transparent
to you the only difference is I get a small commission number four heroes
hoard for you 3d printers out there are tons of selection including Altru tiles
lines and number five my modules on the DMS Guild written for D&D 5th edition
they're pretty good not great but you know good so I've had this stencil for a
couple years I saw it in the store or figured it would come in handy someday
and now it did I used it to airbrush on a few white blooms then I airbrushed a
thin layer over those blooms with a plain green not too much just enough to
tint the white to green and make it look like it's glowing
then with a lime-green color I
airbrushed a smaller area inside the green and lastly with yellow airbrushed
a very small area in the middle
after that the acrylic black base coat was kind of dull so I went to a good
model grade paint this is army painter matte black and just went around and
touched up all the black areas to create an even more bold contrast with the
green the front facades I simply painted with gunmetal then I got out my leftover
nekron water slide transfers and just went to town with them on those silver
facades and here you see it's actually attached to my first attempt at a base
the intent was that it looked like it was in a hyperspace tunnel or something
but it just didn't work colors are off or it's not hovering I don't know but I
tore it off and started over on the base I took 3 CDs and made a sandwich out of
them again using chipboard as spacers
then trace this onto some food box cardstock cut that out and glued it on
for the post to which I would attach the main body I cut a one and a half inch
wide strip of chipboard along with some half inch strips and hot glued those on
perpendicularly to create two axes of rigidity that got hot glued to the base
using a good amount of pressure to bend it to the slight curve of the CD and on
the back of it yet I hot glued some slabs of cardboard to that middle open
area to create an offset eventually that's what gets hot glued to the post
but first paint I base coated with black and then with a toothbrush and some
slightly watered-down white paint I flicked a star field into existence
from there it was back to the same green
lime green and yellow in the airbrush to put down some nebulas it's a good idea
to have some blotches overlapping and others on their own and then a second
star field flick from toothbrush over top then I hot glued it to the post
these are the leftovers from a Necron ghost arc because I've built a doomsday
arc so I assembled the five warriors and painted them up just their fronts and
hot-glued kabob skewers to their spines painted that post black cut it to length
and hot glued it in the bottom compartment five of them fit in there
perfectly at this point is those corner patches are really ugly and the fibrous
texture that chipboard isn't helping things so I'm gonna do what I should
have done before I took food box cardstock and re encased the entire
outside with it lately pre scoring where the folds need to occur give me a nice
clean corner I also made sure to leave the shiny product side out for a
smoother finish at the end from there I painted exactly as I described earlier
and I got this much better here's an example this is not an actual game in
play I just threw down all my models in a scene but you can see how off to the
side of the table are the models that are in reserve for both armies I
remember a comment in response to the teleport areum video that oh this will
help me not forget to bring my reserves in I've definitely done that in game I'm
sure we all have and yeah having this little diorama with lights on it and
stuff on the side of the table you're unlikely to overlook that oh one thing I
forgot to mention I did use the airbrush to lay down some green in all the
corners on the inside that really helped things start to glow when the LEDs are
on just for posterity because I went to the
trouble of setting all this up here's another glamour shot of the
teleport areum got a unit of terminators ready to beam down and another unit to
the right on deck by the way all the terrain you see on this table I've done
in previous episodes so you can check my backlog if you see anything that
interests you and this is on a frontline gaming map really happy with how this
stencil performed for me it's been sitting there for like three years
finally got to use it and I think I'll probably use this technique on my future
nekron terrain buildings and such and just like last time no doubt you're
curious to see what it's like in the pitch dark so I set up sort of a little
area here on my desk at night and here we go
little grainy cuz this cameras really not meant for this but nonetheless looks
pretty sweet pretty imposing those rods really like almost glow in real life
it's pretty cool I had considered doing like a half pipe behind it and painting
that like hyperspace like stars going past but would have been too large
wanted to keep this simpler nekron stuff is so hard to photograph pictures and
video at jet black with high contrast neon over it I just don't know what I'm
doing I know it's cliche but trust me it looks way better in real life in case
you're wondering yes I did have to Google what in Oh bleep was and how to
pronounce it it's a secret underground dungeon if you like this particular
project here's two more you might want to check out also enjoy this community
showcase I'm wild lock thanks for joining and I'll see you next time
